SKIM Proposal
June 2023   |   F9097
Prepared for Alyssa Martin and teamAlpro Sustainability Claims
For this proposal, the conditions apply that are defined in the Master Service Agreement between DANTRADE B.V. and SKIM group B.V.
Nice to be working together again!Thank you for giving us the opportunity to share our view on how to further drive the growth of Alpro by getting the consumers’ perspective on sustainability claims.

The business objective is to create and validate sustainability claims that are consumer friendly (easy to understand) and legally approved.While these are being considered, it is also important to make sure that the claims fit the brand and are unique compared to competitors.Why we’re excited to helpWe are proposing a two-step approach:1)The first step is a claims creation workshop in which we will spend 4-5 hours formulating and narrowing down potential claims to be used in future packaging.2)We will use the claims created and test which ones perform the best using our Unspoken methodology.How we’re going to helpWe value the collaborative spirit of Danone and are excited to pair our analytical rigor with your market and category experience.Besides rigor, our hands-on consultative approach allows for effective translation of results into strategy & actions, and we are looking forward to being part of your growth story.What you want to achieveProposal Summary
DeliverablesMarketsSample§Workshop§Full Report deck§(Online) Debrief sessionUKGermanyItalySweden§QualBites, n=500 in Germany§n = 500 per market§Users and Non-Rejectors of Alpro(Drinks and Yoghurts)
1 | The opportunity2 | Considerations3 | Our approach in detail4 | Timeline and investmentWhat we cando for you
The opportunity

oImmerseinto a sustainability mindset and ensure all parties involved are aligned on the sustainability practices of the brand.oUnderstand and createdifferent claims/narratives around sustainability to fit the Alprobrand and their products. These claims can help Alprodifferentiate versus its competitors. §Across countries, language differences and legal regulations should be considered.oGet consumer feedbackto the claims to understand which perform best and why? Are there messages that even show a bridge between sustainability and taste or sustainability and health in consumer minds?Alpro has found a challenge with claims under the topic of sustainability. As a whole, the topic is gaining awareness from the consumer perspective. Consumers want to make more conscious choices (part of which can be the choice for plant based rather than traditional dairy), and Alpro wants to highlight its sustainability efforts to consumers. Business BackgroundObjectives

SKIM will provide answers to the following research objectivesBusiness OpportunityThere is a need to identify what claims, related to sustainability, consumers find most relevant and convincing in order to buy Alpro products. Through this research, Alpro can gain insights based on SKIM knowledge around the topic, as well as collecting new insights specific to the brand, to see how they can improve their links to sustainability.The goal is to identify consumer friendly claim that highlights Alpro’ssustainability efforts and benefits. oWhat (sustainability) claims are the most attractive to consumers?§Why do these claims perform better/worse?§How do these claims perform on KPIs?oWhich claims ladder up to health and/or taste benefits?oHow do health/taste related claims perform versus those that only cue sustainability?oWhich claims generate the highest purchase intent?
Considerations

Claims Generation WorkshopThe base of the claims generation workshop is recommended to stay in line with Danone’s Claims Lab. However, given the specific nature of sustainability claims, it will be good to make some adjustments. Setting the scene: it is important for all participants to understand the role of a sustainability claim –it will not replace the main messaging for the brand.Getting familiar with sustainability messaging: which claim inspiration is already out there that shows a consumer centric way of sustainability messaging?Assessing what is possible from the start: for this workshop we understand the benefit of having someone who represents the legal department in the room. There is no point in spending a lot of time on claims that are not legally acceptable.In general, for the Claims Lab it will be important to get a good variety of participants. If the different markets are present,it might be good to facilitate time outside of the workshop for them to catch-up. This will allow for more focus during the workshop. Claim ComparabilityWhen testing the claims against each other, we must make sure that the claims being tested are all related to sustainability,and that in order to get accurate results, we cannot test sustainability claims against first priority claims such as taste, or health. It will be interesting to explore which sustainability messaging is also able to cue taste and /or health benefitsWhat is allowed and what do consumers want to hear?Finding a balance between claims that are allowed (e.g., legally) and that are consumer centric will be difficult. During theworkshop SKIM will provide the team with education on the golden rules for claim creation. As mentioned above, there should also be someone who is a gatekeeper on what is legally allowed.  The Use of Eco labelsGenerally, recognised eco-labels allow brands to show their sustainability efforts. Considering that Danone has eco-labels that can be used, we can test which ones perform better than others. To do this, we recommend testing them using two separate Unspoken tasks due to the fact that in atrade-off, consumers tend to favour eco-labels over claims. If Danone would like to explore the best combination of claims and eco-labels shown together, a different set-up for phase two is required. Hence that would be something to further discuss. Country NuancesNaturally, countries could have different priorities, or regulations, leading to a different set of claims to be tested. In order to allow for both comparability and flexibility, our recommendation is to have 75% of the same claims across markets and the remaining claims can be more tailored to account forthese local nuances. Factors shaping our recommended approach

1. Be specific -Being specific in describing what benefits are being offered helps create a vivid picture of the brand promise in the consumer’s mind. This decreases psychological distance and creates a concrete mental representation about the product and its benefits.2. Use simple language  -Avoid jargon and complex or ambiguous language to ensure consumers understand what is being said. Without comprehension, there is no meaning and without meaning the probability to successfully project a tangible brand promise is limited.
ConsumersWhen deciding what brand to choose, people often form a mental image of the productexperienceand emotional state they desireBrandsTo trigger consumers to choose your brand over competition, it should project a promise through its words that matchesthe mental image consumers have in mindMatch       Connect       Trigger ActionReducingpsychological distance helps close the gap between what the brand offers (projected product experience) and what the consumer wants (desired product experience). Strong claims contribute to lowering the distance and creating a meaningful connectionbetween brand and consumer that triggersthe consumer to choose your brand over competition3. Be positive  -A consumer’s desired product experience and end state is always positive, so using a positive tone of voice is key. A negative tonality could create a distortion between the positive image people have in mind and the promise projected by the brand.4. Cue senses -Use words that encourage mental imagery by triggering memories, emotions and reactions linked to sensorial cues stored in memory. Examples are words like ‘taste’, ‘touch’, ‘enjoy’ or direct references like ‘creamy’, ‘silky’ or ‘melts in your mouth’.WHAT ELSE TO KEEP IN MIND?5. Be respectful –Avoid being condescending, presumptuous or offending. It is not unusual to unintentionally make judgmental assumptions about consumers in claims, so be careful not to.PSYCHOLOGICAL DISTANCE is a concept in human psychology that describes how concrete an object or event feels. Strong claims drive short-term consumer behavior by lowering the distance between what a brand promises and a consumer desires –SO HOW CAN WE REDUCE IT?SKIM Claim Creation Guidelines
6. Put the key benefit first -You only have a split second to capture a consumer’s attention, so it is critical to open your message with what matters to them most.

Show tangible impact that is relevantFocus on the positive and be clear & simpleState 100% whenever possibleIncluding sustainability drives uniquenessDon’t try to replace primary benefits#
11
5 principles to consider for sustainability messages in particular

Consumers relate sustainability most closely to health and price. But it can also ladder up further to quality and taste
TasteMore mindful production, resources and employment, less shortcuts may make sustainable products cost moreLess processing means fresher and better ingredients SUSTAINABILITY/ECO-FRIENDLINESSHealthPriceQuality
Source: SKIM studySustainable products use fewer chemicals, pesticides, and preservativesHigher-quality raw materials, locally sourced (France), and processing means a higher-quality product
Our approach in detail

At SKIM, we take a consultative approach with our clients
Understanding Your Needs Our starting point will be consultation and collaboration with the Alpro team. This collaboration starts with a kick-off session and then flows through everything we do, from stakeholder alignment toa final presentation.Upfront AlignmentKicking off the projectbetween SKIM and Alpro research teams ensures that we have everything we need to tailor this research toyour needs.Collating InputsCreating and gathering the inputs (i.e., the claims to be used) for the study will be a collaborative process. Together, we will collate the final inputs from the workshop and integrate them into the consumer study.

For this business question, we propose an extended two-step approach:
Have a workshop with key stakeholders and other expert views that work on creating claims together. Participants will immerse themselves in the topic of sustainability claims, and ideate and refine claims. The output of the workshop is a list of claims that can go to a copywriter (and legal if needed) for a final refinement. Phase 1b: WorkshopInputs from Phase 1 will be evaluated in order to shed light on the most relevant and impactful claims for consumers.Here, we can understand:•Which claims are most motivating to buy Alpro•Why certain claims are more/less motivating•How the claims perform on specific KPIs (e.g,. purchase intent, relevance, uniqueness, brand fit)•Which claims ladder up to cue health / taste benefits•What is the impact of cueing health / taste benefitsPhase 2: Consumer feedback
Phase 1a: QualBites
A Qual-inspired methodology atquantitative pace andscale. This pre-phase will help us explore consumers’ understanding of the link between sustainability and taste/health. This can serve as inspiration for the claims ideation in the workshop.
Phase 1: OptionalQual Bites

Qual-inspired methodology, atquantitative pace andscaleüMore illuminating open endsversus regular surveysüA way toscratch the surface more into the ‘why’üA way to get moreconsumer languagearounda topic areaüCan send out to alarger sampleüShort & engaging, easy to understandüWritten usingqualitative / projective questioning techniquesOnly 3 questions are asked, using the Funnel Approach
Respondents are asked to write/tell a story, respond to a situation or explain associations Sent to a quant panelAn open-ended question survey, containing maximum 3 questions.(plus, a short screener if needed)What Who How

Qual Bite thought starters 
Meet Hellen. Hellen needs some help to understand what sustainability in food products means. Please describe what the first things are that come to mind for you in helping her understand this topic. Q1 Q2 Q3Starting with qual bites will help us understand what language consumers use to talk about sustainability and which words they use to make the association to health. Learnings from this phase can allow us to aid the process in the Claims Lab when trying to ideate sustainability claims that ladder up to health benefits. 
Which words would you use to help Hellen understand the benefit of sustainability on her (and her family’s) health?Hellen read somewhere about regenerative agriculture. However, she is not entirely sure what the benefits of regenerative agriculture are. Tell us which benefits you think are important coming from regenerative agriculture? Can you also link this to health?
NOTE: These questions serve as an example and can/will be adjusted.

output examples
•Consumer generated functional and emotional themes •Consumer stories that contextualise the themes•Cultural differences in reactions to a topic •Identify popular consumer language
In contrast with traditional survey open ends, the responses we receive from Qual Bites are more detailed.Responses to projective story-based questions around brand personalities should yield rich insights.

We recommend (initially) focusing on one market for QualBitesWho we will speak toScreening Criteria•Women, Men•Age > 18 yo•Responsible for HH shopping•Users and Non-rejecters of AlproFieldwork specifications
N=100Assumed Incidence Rate > 20%< 5 min lengthDevice agnostic survey

SKIM’s role in the workshop
Contrary to all the participants who work with these products every day, SKIM will be able to bring an external eye to act as a representative of the consumer. OutsiderModeratorWe will bring our expertise on claims creation and testing. We will share our best practices and guide participants to ensure the golden rules are applied (refining phase). Claims ExpertSince everyone’s time is valuable, we will make sure to respect the planned time per phase to make the most out of the workshop Timekeeper
SKIM will moderate the whole workshop. This means that we will be facilitatingand leading the steps and discussions. We ensure that everyone remains engaged, and the output is actionable.

Input / output of the workshopInput
Output•List of claims ready for copy writing and testing•Objectives of the session/brand•Open mindset of the participants•(Optional) Brand/background information as pre-read (to be provided by Danone)
Phase 2: Consumer Screening

This is a carbon neutral product
Yes!
Interacts with stimuli in a natural wayMeasures subconscious processes of the brainReduces response biases across global marketsIncreases consumer engagementSwiping, scrolling and tapping on our phones is the new normal. Unspoken replicates this natural behavior and ensures that we measure in the same way as people communicate with the world around them on a daily basis.Traditional methods tend to focus on rational processes. By using an intuitive interface, Unspoken finds a better balance between rational and emotional (system 1) drivers. The more rational a method the more prone it is to response biases. Asian and Latin countries can be especially sensitive to this. Unspoken has been proven to reduce response bias and reveal more true preferences. Read more hereThe age of instant gratification has reduced attention spans significantly. Unspoken has been shown to generate much higher engagement than traditional surveys and delivers better data quality as a result.  At the base of our intuitive approach is our Unspoken methodology Try it for yourself:  link to demoDo you find this message appealing?
100% recyclable packaging

There will be max. 20 claims in the studyThe research design consists of 6 modules, including 
KPI rating
Consumers will evaluate several claims on different KPIs4Consumers indicate how likely they are to purchase the Alprobrand in the future3Purchase IntentSwiping exercise to measure absoluteappeal (metric TBD) of each claim through a binary swipe exercise1Swiping Module
Trade-off exercise to determine relative motivation to buy(metric TBD)2Trade-off Module
Deep Dive
Understanding whyconsumers like / dislike some claims5
First, respondents go through a screener to assess if they are the right audience for this study. This screener can also includecertain current usage questions (e.g. by ingredient type) if specific splits of the sample are needed. Health / taste perceptionConsumers will evaluate claims on their ability to cue health / taste6

The swiping moduleMethodologyThis approach is particularly good for measuring initial reactions –emotional, automatic, and associative –to stimuli. This module is aimed at determining the absolute appeal of each product. The objective of the swiping module is to establish the absolute appeal (metric TBD) of all the claims.Through several swiping exercises, consumers reveal which claims they prefer.Unspoken can be tailored to the most relevant metric for Alpro  e.g., Appeal, motivating to buy, superior, relevant, etc. Let’s discuss!1
#1 high-protein drink
Do you find this message appealing?YESNo100% Plant-Based

We will show 4 different claims at random and ask consumers to choose the option that would motivate them most to buy (TBD) Alpro products. There will be multiple screens.We will then get a ranking of all the claims by motivation to buy (TBD). Once consumers have indicated their absolute appeal for the different claims, we will determine their relative motivation to buy (TBD) thanks to an intuitive tapping trade-off exercise. In this module, consumers make trade-offs between competing options. 2The trade-off moduleMethodology
Made from recyclable materials
Which message would motivate you most to purchase Alpro products?
#1 plant-based drink100% recycled materials100% plant based

Purchase IntentMethodologyAfter the swiping and trade off modules, we will ask the purchase intent of the brand in the context of  several claims. 3
How likely are you to purchase YoPROproducts in the future if they say the following messages?
Very unlikelyVery likely60%Zero plastic packaging
Very unlikelyVery likely40%Healthy high protein snackRecyclable materials
How likely are you to purchase Alpro products in the future if they say the following messages?

To gain further understanding on consumers choices and ensure that the claims convey the desired effect, consumers will evaluate some claims on several KPIs (e.g., new and different, relevant, believable, superior). KPI ratingMethodologyTo understand how claims are perceived, we will include some KPI assessments on the claims. We can include up to 4 KPIs in this study. 4
Please rate this message on the following: #1 high-protein drink Is new and differentIs relevantIs believable
Less carbon emission

Deep dive module –Qualitative FeedbackMethodologyAt last, we will deep dive on the qualitative evaluation of the claims. We will ask consumers what they liked or disliked about their most and least preferred claims from the trade off exercise, and why. 5
You found the following message more motivating than others. What do you likeabout this message and why?#1 high-protein drink 
Locally sourced ingredients

Health / Taste perceptionMethodologyFinally, consumers will be asked to rate a random subset of claims on their ability to cue health / taste. Even though this is asked in a stated way, we will use the results of this assessment to get to the derived importance of health / taste perception in the evaluation of the claims. (see next slides)6
How likely are you to purchase YoPROproducts in the future if they say the following messages?
Very unlikelyVery likely60%Zero plastic packaging
Very unlikelyVery likely40%Healthy high protein snackRecyclable materials
How much do expect a product with this claim to give you health benefits?
Very much
Very muchNot at allNot at all#1 high-protein drink
How important is it for you that a product gives you…YESNoHealth benefits

Shapley values regression
37For each independent variable (perception) we measure the strength of the direct relationship between itself and the dependent (Unspoken preference) after stripping out its relationship between the other independent variablesResults –quantification of the most to least important perceptions for each claim
42%20%16%11%11%Is good for my healthIs good for the environmentIs tastyIs nutritionalIs appropriate for my whole familyImportance
Shapley values

How to interpret the resultsMapping perceptions into actionable quadrants
MUST HAVE PERCEPTIONSPerceptionsthat are stated to be important, but do not have a correlation with a consumer’s claim preference. We need to at least meet expectations.CLEAR BASIS OF CLAIM PREFERENCEPerceptionsthat are both stated to be important and have a high correlation to a consumer’s claim preference. Strong areas for claim differentiation.LESS-CONSCIOUS BASIS OF CLAIM PREFERENCEPerceptionsthat consumer's can not / do not identify at a stated level but do have a high correlation with a consumer’s claim preference. Strong potential for building claim differentiation.LOW PRIORITYPerceptionsthat are low stated importance and little correlation with a consumer’s claim preference.DERIVED ImportanceSTATEDImportance

One of Danone’s (favourite!) strategic partners, consulting and collaborating with Danone S&I, conducting global market research to have parent’s  opinions central to business decisions.We reach parents, patients, HCPs using a range of agile, interactive and intuitive research techniques. We help Danone test innovations, communications, pricing strategies, understand their journeys… fundamentally what decisions do people make regarding your products and why. 
David VoxlinSustainability Director, SKIMWho are SKIM?

SocialMeSKIM Psychological Distance Model

Strong messages lower people’s inhibition to act and increase perceived value
Lower inhibition to actClaims with low psychological distance reduce the activity in the brain that manages inhibition, increasing the likelihood consumers engage with your brand and act positively upon it as a resultIncrease subjective valueClaims that are lower in psychological distance also increase the subjective value the consumer assigns to the option in front of them and positively impacts their decision making in favor of that brandVentromedial prefrontal cortex (vmPFC)ACC and inferior frontal gyrus
Source: MRI research conducted by SKIM and the University of Amsterdam
Principles for Effective Sustainability Comms

Show tangible impact and go all-inKeep it simple and avoid jargonComplement, don’t replace, primary benefits
20
3 key principles to consider for effective sustainability messaging
Complement, don’t replace primary benefits Include message benefits or emotions that the customer is in need of and are relevant to the category
Cleaning products need to emphasise efficacy first, then give consumers sustainability as an addedbenefit
Burgers need to be indulgent first, then guilt free. Veggie burgers in the 1990’s usually fell on the first hurdle
Keep it Simple & Avoid Technical JargonUse simple language to ensure your message is understood. Avoid jargon or technical lingo
Consumers do not understand “KG CO2e/KG”, but they know that “A” and the colour green means “good”
Show Tangible Impact & Go All-InTry to be definitive, use 100% where possible, and describe the concrete benefits your product will deliver
A pack that is 50% sustainable unfortunately brings consumers minds to the other 50% that is not
A message containing the promise of 100% sustainability is much more reassuring for consumers
How to create effective sustainability comms

Sustainability comms need to be considered from both a tactical and a strategic perspectiveTactical         (Short-term)Strategic         (Long-term)
Increase market shareRevenue growthNew customer segmentsIncrease considerationGrow and protect shareSustainable price premiumStrengthen brandProtect category position
Source: SKIM study

4 key factors determine the success of a sustainability message
ChoicePerceptionNoticeabilityEngagement
1. Does it get noticed?2. Is it understood, liked, relevant and trusted?3. Does it affect product choice?4. How engaged is the consumer in sustainability? 
Source: SKIM study

Consumers relate sustainability most closely to health and price. It can ladder to quality and taste, which ecolabels help promote
TasteSustainable products use fewer chemicals, pesticides, and preservatives
More mindful production, resources and employment, less shortcuts may make sustainable products cost moreHigher-quality raw materials, locally sourced (France), and processing means a higher-quality productLess processing means fresher and better ingredients SUSTAINABILITY/ECO-FRIENDLINESSHealthPriceQuality
Source: SKIM study

Integrated claims combine a familiar territory with sustainability to create an even stronger claim
Primary Attribute (e.g. Taste)Secondary Attribute(e.g. Sustainability)In Combination(e.g. Delicious & Sustainable)= Non-negotiable= Nice to Have= Amazing!
Source. SKIM client study (brand changed)

EcoImpact is an example of a high-performing label
Simple rating scale with color-coding to support meaningEarth imagery creates a clear link to the environment
8-point scale offers additional granularityBright colors draw attention

Packaging as a catalyst

Packaging is a visible and felt aspect for customersUnlike many other sustainability efforts that are more abstract, such as climate change, packaging is one of the most accessible 
Recycling is a habitual behaviour internalised over decades Plastic waste has been a top environmental concern over the past 5 years

Customers are concerned with packaging and are actively looking for solutions
Green Matters“Unfortunately, finding zero-waste baby formula is extremely difficult. Whenever possible, buy formula in recyclable containers to minimize carbon footprint and overall waste.”
Packaging Insights
“Parents report deep concern over the environmental impact of infant food packaging: 70% of Spanish parents agree that the environmental impact of baby/toddler food and drink packaging is concerning” Packaging Insights"Parents are looking for sustainable packaging options that maintain the same level of convenience, durability and portability" –SinaHilbert, Sustainability Lead, Nestle Gerber
"That’s so frustrating 
😓you’d think with the amount that is sold the big companies might have had it raised a lot as an issue and worked on different packaging!" -Parent on not being able to dispose non-recyclable tubs of AptamilMum's Net

Bringing It All Together

The SKIM approach to creating a strong sustainability strategy
Sustainability Workshop
We run a workshop to align and engage all stakeholders and create the starting point for our strategy. Together we generate ideas to be further refined in the next steps.Claims & labels Refinement Based on the inputs from the workshop, we do a final test where we narrow down the labels and claims to obtain the winners we are happy to proceed with.  Revenue & Brand GrowthWe then run a choice model including our winning labels and claim to understand what the strongest combination is and what the revenue and market share impact is.Activation & PlaybookBased on the customer insights, we will develop a strategy and a playbook. We then socialize it through workshops with all stakeholders and plan pilots and implementation together.Pilot Initiatives
Using the evidence-based playbook we start rolling out pilots for further research or market testing to gather learnings, iterate, and scale. 
13245

It is important to ensure that any claims are science-based and independently verified –involve technical teams in the process
Green claims are everywhere: ocean-friendly t-shirts, carbon-neutral bananas, bee-friendly juices, 100% CO2-compensated deliveries and so on. Unfortunately, way too often these claims are made with no evidence and justification whatsoever. This opens the door to greenwashing and puts companies making genuinely sustainable products at a disadvantage.Frans Timmermans, Executive Vice-President for the European Green Deal“”

AI Tool: Creating a Client-Friendly Claims Workshop Assistant Hackathon 2023
oPre-Work: Please read through this section before the Hackathon kicks off

Background & ObjectivesIntroductionOver the course of the week, we will work to determine the objectives for this tool, as well as the requirements to build it to best meet client needs. oSKIM is not new to claims/message generation workshops. However, with the rise of AI, we are curious how we can utilize this technology to help provide an “assistant” in workshops to help clients become more involved with the brainstorm and message refinement. We see two main use cases for this tool: §1) Helping to brainstorm what we should be writing claims about §2) Refining brainstormed claims to go into testing *oThe second use case is our current goal for this tool. Specifically, we want it to be able to provide words/sentences to use in messaging & help with refining towards SKIM’s messaging best practices. oThe goal is to create a client-friendly tool to be used on accounts where the client is open to automation (otherwise, it will still be a valuable tool to have on our end internally as well)!

Background & Objectives, ContinuedIntroductionOver the course of the week, we will work to determine the objectives for this tool, as well as the requirements to build it to best meet client needs. oA few workshops have already been conducted where AI has been used as a “help desk” in messaging refinement. However, we hope to have  SKIM-generated tool to use instead. §Potential To-Do: To help prepare, you can review a previous workshop deck and output that utilized an AI help desk previously. We will discuss this workshop briefly in our Kick-off. You can find all documents here:§Workshop Deck§Output directly from workshop(note in particular the tab with AI-generated claims)§Post-it groupings from workshop§Ideated claims (utilizing workshop output and AI)oThe goal of the Hackathon is to create the backlog for Qiurui to then create this tool. This entails:§What we expect the client to have as input into the tool §What we want to be loaded into it/prompts §What we want as the output

Pre-Work IntroductionOver the course of the week, we will work to determine the objectives for this tool, as well as the requirements to build it to best meet client needs. oTo help prepare for the Hackathon, it would be good to get a base understanding of AI tools & how to write a good prompt. Please review the below deck created about prompting. There is also a lot on YouTube about this topic, two such videos are below for review:§Prompting deck§YouTube video & another optionoAdditionally, please review the below spec doc and output from a Pandora tool. This one is likely more complex than ours, but will serve as an example of what Qiurui needs from us to create the tool:§Pandora Functional Specs §Pandora Wireframe oWhile reviewing both is all that is needed as pre-work, if you have time and thoughts on where to get started, you can go ahead and add them to the below docs:§Claims Workshop AI Functional Specs§Claims Workshop AI Wireframe
